title: KPMG Moves U.K. Employees From Advisory to Audit Business
text:
KPMG LLP is moving about 750 U.K. employees, including some partners, from its advisory business to its audit division to prepare for potential regulatory changes.

The professional services firm said it is working to give its audit practice greater independence from the rest of the business.

“As you would expect, this work involves moving a number of people from the advisory side of our business into audit and vice versa,” a spokesman said.

The reorganization comes as lawmakers and regulators discuss a structural overhaul of the accounting and audit sector in Britain.

Several high-profile corporate collapses have resulted in increased scrutiny over the conduct of Big Four accounting firms Deloitte LLP, Ernst & Young LLP, KPMG and PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP.

The U.K. Competition and Markets Authority in April recommended an operational split between professional services firms’ audit and consulting businesses, while members of a parliamentary committee have called for a structural breakup.

The U.K. government has yet to respond to the proposals.

KPMG employs around 6,000 people in its U.K. audit practice. Its advisory business, with around 10,000 employees, supports the audit team when needed, KPMG said. The shuffling will conclude at the end of the month, the end of the company’s financial year.

KPMG earlier this year said it would increase oversight of its U.K. audit unit.

The company is still under investigation by the U.K. Financial Reporting Council for its audits of Carillion PLC, a British construction firm that went out of business at the beginning of last year.

The Financial Reporting Council, Britain’s regulator for audit and accounting, on Thursday criticized as ineffective the quality of mandatory transparency reports published by U.K. audit firms, including by KPMG.

“The FRC is concerned that many firms treat the reports wrongly as a marketing tool which damages their perception among stakeholders and limits their usefulness,” the watchdog said in a release.

PwC said its transparency report sets out the actions the company is taking to improve audit quality, while Ernst & Young said it would act on the FRC’s feedback.

Deloitte, KPMG and Mazars LLP declined to comment on the FRC review. BDO LLP didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.

description: The professional services firm said it is working to give its audit practice greater independence from the rest of the business.
